summary:
What is a waste exemption and is this a more suitable option for you than an environmental permit?

This is the main topic in this discussion, where today we're going to find out.

children.value: Waste Exemptions
Last updated May 1, 2024

For those working in the waste sector, it can be quite a daunting task making sure you have all of the relevant licenses and documentation. One thing to always ensure you have is an environmental permit however, there are some exceptions to this rule.

So, what is a waste exemption anyway? What makes a person or company exempt from posessing a valid waste license in circumstances where others would be required to do so? And, are you exempt from having a an environmental permit?
These are just some of the questions we'll answer in todays article.
What is a waste exemption?

A waste exemption is a specific waste operation or process that is exempt from needing an environmental permit. There four broad categories for waste exemption, each sub-categorised into smaller more fine-grained regulations or references. Each of these waste exemption types has with it it's own set of regulations and conditions it must abide by, along with certain limits that it must not exceed. There are some exemptions that do not need to be registered. An individual storing their own waste, for example, would not require a waste exemption, as they would not need an environmental permit to perform such actions anyway. However under most circumstances, either a valid environmental permit or a waste exemption would be required. For more information on exemptions you do not need to register, please see the

For those that are required to register their particular waste exemption(s), when they do the details of their company and registration will be added to the environment agencies public register of waste exemptions, with the exceptions being waste exemptions covered by national security.

How much does it cost?
It's completely free to register a waste exemption but unlike an environmental permit, they have to be re-registered every 3 years, irregardless of the nature of your waste operations.
However, there's one exception to the above rule. The exception is the
T11 WEEE exemption
, which covers the repairs or refurbishment of waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE). The price for this is £1,221 for 3 years.
